lecturer.name: Utrecht University, Utrecht, the Netherlands
lecturer.summary: Course taught in English for first-year Master’s students in Human–Computer Interaction, combining lectures with hands-on learning. The course covers research study design and hypothesis testing, including data preparation and parametric and non-parametric statistical analyses.
highlights: Taught annually for four consecutive years
Co-designed the course curriculum and learning objectives
Planned the course schedule and set up the e-learning environment (on Blackboard and Brightspace)
Designed and delivered several full lectures
Designed and coordinated multiple hands-on practical sessions with formative exercises
Designed, graded, and provided feedback on multiple home assignments and the final exam

lecturer.name: Utrecht University, Utrecht, the Netherlands
lecturer.summary: Course taught in English for first-year Master’s students from different programs (Human-Computer Interaction, Aritificial Intelligence, Business Informatics, etc.).  The course offers a practice-oriented learning experience in which students engage in a user-centered design process where they conduct user research, and iteratively prototype solutions based on user feedback. The course combines lectures, prototyping lab sessions, and skills workshops (e.g., 3D printing).
highlights: Taught annually for two consecutive years
Revised and enhanced existing course materials, and delivered several full lectures
Designed and coordinated 3D modeling skills workshops
Planned the course schedule and set up the e-learning environment (on Blackboard)
Supervised multiple hands-on practical and lab sessions
Graded presentations as well as formative and summative assignments

supervision.name: Utrecht University, Utrecht, the Netherlands
supervision.position: Daily supervisor, Master thesis, Human-Computer Interaction
supervision.summary: Daily supervision includes weekly meetings and frequent formative feedback on research methods and written parts of the thesis.
highlights: Thesis title: Speech Prediction And Real-time Suggestions (SPARS) for people who stutter

Topic: Stuttering affects millions of people worldwide and can negatively impact communication, mental health, and social well-being. Existing therapies and technologies often lack real-time, personalized support during everyday speech. This work explores an AI-based approach that provides immediate, tailored word suggestions while speaking, aiming to reduce stuttering and support more fluent communication.
The thesis is currently in the process of being turned into a paper; submission expected early 2026.

supervision.name: Utrecht University, Utrecht, the Netherlands
supervision.position: Daily (co-)supervisor, Master thesis, Computing Science and Artificial Intelligence
supervision.summary: Daily supervision includes weekly meetings and frequent formative feedback on research methods and written parts of the thesis. This student had 2 daily supervisors.
highlights: Thesis title: Learning Complementary Latent Representations of Unknown Dynamics using Predictive Encoder-Decoder Models in Control Systems

Topic: Many control systems contain hidden parameters that are difficult to learn from data alone. The thesis introduces a model that separates short-term and long-term information to better capture these hidden effects while limiting error accumulation over long sequences. The model is tested with a simulated race car scenario.

supervision.name: Utrecht University, Utrecht, the Netherlands
supervision.position: First supervisor, Bachelor thesis, Information Sciences
supervision.summary: First supervision includes weekly meetings, frequent formative feedback on research methods and written parts of the thesis, and final grading.
highlights: Thesis title: Deceptive Design Occupies Our Minds: How Dark Patterns Affect Cognitive Load

Topic: Dark patterns are deceptive design practices that can influence users to make unintended choices. This work explores how such interface elements may affect users’ cognitive load and decision-making.

evaluation and improvements.title: Course evaluations
evaluation and improvements.summary: Each year, each course is evaluated by the students via Caracal. The students are asked to rate the course on a scale from 1 to 10, and to answer which elements of the course should be kept, and which should be changed. Based on this feedback from students, we adapt the course for the following year (e.g., adding a practical on a certain topic that the students judged a valuable addition).

evaluation and improvements.title: Supervision evaluations
evaluation and improvements.summary: After the graduation of each student (Master and Bachelor) I supervised, a survey I designed is sent to them by e-mail. They can answer a few questions about my supervision style, namely, about my flexibility, the frequency of meetings, the quality of feedback, and overall what they preferred about my supervision and what changes they would suggest. Based on the feedback I get, I can improve how I supervise theses for students.
